title: 113_hr3357
content:
The "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" aims to assist States in enhancing the knowledge, credentials, compensation, and professional development of early childhood educators in early childhood education programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "early childhood education program" includes Head Start Program, State-funded prekindergarten program, licensed child care for prekindergarten children, and special education preschool. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965.

SEC. 4. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Secretary of Education, with consultation from the Secretary of Health and Human Services, can award grants to States for implementing activities in section 6. Applications for grants are authorized. Each State seeking a grant under this Act must submit an application to the Secretary of Education, including details of their early childhood professional development system developed in collaboration with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care. The State's childhood professional development system was developed in collaboration with various stakeholders, including the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care. A State agency was designated to administer the grant program. The State's childhood professional development system involves collaboration with stakeholders such as the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care. A State agency is designated to administer the grant program, which includes oversight structures, professional standards, career lattices, and coordination with higher education entities. The State's childhood professional development system includes oversight structures, professional standards, career lattices, and coordination with higher education entities. It encourages articulation agreements between two- and four-year institutions of higher education. Encouragement of articulation agreements between two- and four-year institutions of higher education, credit-bearing opportunities, and recognition of prior learning and expertise. Accessibility of higher education for working learners through offering college courses at convenient times and locations, with a focus on rural areas. The curr_chunk discusses articulation agreements, accessible higher education for working learners, support for adult learners from diverse backgrounds, use of workforce data, and financing over time. SEC. 6. STATE USE OF FUNDS. A State receiving a grant under this Act must use the funds for scholarships covering tuition, fees, materials, transportation, and release time for preschool teachers pursuing a bachelor's degree in early childhood education. Additionally, funds can support preschool teachers with a bachelor's degree in a different field to obtain credentials or licensure. To support preschool teachers in early childhood education programs to attain credentials or licensure demonstrating competence in the field and increase compensation for teachers enrolled in early childhood education degree programs. To support preschool teachers in early childhood education programs by providing ongoing professional development opportunities that address all areas of child development and learning. This includes increasing compensation for teachers enrolled in early childhood education degree programs and ensuring parity of compensation upon completion of the degree. The program aims to offer professional development opportunities for preschool teachers and teacher assistants in early childhood education. It covers areas like child development, teacher-child interaction, family engagement, and cultural competence for diverse children and families. The Act emphasizes that grant funds should supplement, not replace, existing federal, state, and local funds for early childhood educator preparation. States receiving funds must maintain or increase their financial support for these activities. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
